questions.question: What are sex-linked traits?
options: Traits controlled by genes on sex chromosomes (X or Y)
Traits that are expressed exclusively in a single gender
Traits that are only relevant to the reproductive system
Traits that periodically skip generations due to mutation
questions.explanation: Sex-linked traits are determined by genes located on the sex chromosomes (X or Y). Most sex-linked traits are X-linked because the X chromosome has many genes, while the Y chromosome has few.

questions.question: Why are males more likely to express X-linked recessive disorders?
options: Males have only one X chromosome, so one recessive allele shows the trait
Males possess inherently weaker alleles on their single X chromosome
Females have biological protections against recessive genetic mutations
These specific disorders only target male physiological structures
questions.explanation: Males are XY - they have only one X chromosome. If that X carries a recessive allele, there's no second X to provide a dominant allele to mask it. Females (XX) need two copies to show the trait.

questions.question: A woman who is a carrier for an X-linked recessive disorder has what genotype?
options: She has one normal allele and one disorder allele (heterozygous)
She has two identical recessive disorder alleles (homozygous)
She has two identical normal dominant alleles (homozygous)
She lacks a second X chromosome and functions like a male
questions.explanation: A carrier female has one normal dominant allele and one recessive disorder allele on her X chromosomes (XᴺXᴰ). She doesn't show the disorder but can pass it to offspring.

questions.question: Which pattern shows a sex-linked recessive trait in a pedigree?
options: More males affected, often skips generations
Only females affected, passes directly to all male offspring
Statistically equal numbers of males and females affected
Only males pass the phenotype directly to their daughters
questions.explanation: X-linked recessive traits appear more in males, can skip generations when passed through carrier females, and are never passed from father to son (fathers give Y to sons).

questions.question: A man with an X-linked recessive disorder marries a woman who is not a carrier. What is true about their children?
options: All daughters will be carriers, all sons will be normal
All children will express the phenotypic disorder
All daughters will express the disorder, all sons will be carriers
All children will be genetically and phenotypically normal
questions.explanation: Affected father (XᴰY) gives Xᴰ to all daughters, normal mother (XᴺXᴺ) gives Xᴺ to all children. Daughters: XᴺXᴰ (carriers). Sons: XᴺY (normal, get Y from father).

questions.question: What is the chance that a carrier mother and normal father will have a son with an X-linked recessive disorder?
options: 25% (or 50% of sons)
50% (or 100% of sons)
0% (sons cannot inherit X-linked traits from the mother)
75% (the statistical majority of male offspring)
questions.explanation: Carrier mother (XᴺXᴰ) × Normal father (XᴺY). Each son has 50% chance of getting Xᴰ from mother (affected) vs Xᴺ (normal). Overall among all children: 25% chance of affected son.

questions.question: Which of these is an example of an X-linked recessive disorder in humans?
options: Color blindness
Down syndrome
Huntington's disease
Cystic fibrosis
questions.explanation: Red-green color blindness is X-linked recessive. About 8% of males have it, but only 0.5% of females (need two copies). Other examples: hemophilia, Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

questions.question: Can a father pass an X-linked trait to his son?
options: No, fathers pass Y chromosomes to sons
Yes, all paternal traits are inherited by male offspring
Only if the specific trait is expressed as dominant
Only if the maternal parent is also a carrier for the trait
questions.explanation: Fathers give Y chromosomes to sons (to make them male), and X chromosomes to daughters. So X-linked traits cannot pass from father to son, only to daughters.

questions.question: What is a 'carrier' in genetics?
options: Someone who has one copy of a recessive allele but doesn't show the trait
Someone who has the disease and can spread it through the population
Someone who is genetically immune to a specific metabolic disorder
Someone who possesses two identical dominant alleles for a single trait
questions.explanation: A carrier has one recessive allele for a disorder but doesn't show symptoms because they have a dominant normal allele. They can pass the recessive allele to offspring.

questions.question: How does understanding sex-linked inheritance help in genetic counseling?
options: It helps predict risks for sons vs daughters and identify carriers
It guarantees that all inherited genetic disorders can be cured
It proves that only male patients should be tested for genetic risk
It demonstrates that all recessive genetic disorders are preventable
questions.explanation: Understanding sex-linked patterns helps counselors: calculate different risks for male vs female children, identify female carriers in families, and provide accurate family planning advice.

questions.question: If a woman has an X-linked recessive disorder, what must be true about her parents?
options: Her father must have the disorder and her mother must be at least a carrier
Both parents must be phenotypically normal to pass the trait
Only her mother needs to express the phenotypic disorder
Her parents' genotypes have no statistical impact on the outcome
questions.explanation: For a female to have an X-linked recessive disorder (XᴰXᴰ), she must get Xᴰ from both parents. So: father must be affected (XᴰY), and mother must be at least a carrier (XᴺXᴰ or XᴰXᴰ).

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You understand sex-linked inheritance thoroughly.
scoreMessages.70: Good job! Review why males are more often affected and carrier concepts.
scoreMessages.50: Satisfactory. Focus on X chromosome inheritance patterns.
